data.title: Amy Winehouse Video: Grammy Awards glory as singer wins five gongs
data.meta_description: Amy Winehouse won five Grammy awards, including record and song of the year for Rehab.
data.text:
Amy Winehouse was the star of last night's Grammy Awards ceremony, after picking up five gongs including song of the year for her track Rehab.

The troubled singer also bagged best new artist, best pop album for Back to Black and best female pop vocal.

However, the 24-year-old could not travel to the US to accept her awards in person because her visa application was originally turned down. It was later granted but not in time for her to make the ceremony.

Instead she performed You Know I’m No Good and Rehab at a London studio in front of a small audience and via satellite.

When she heard she had won record of the year, she looked stunned and turned around to embrace her band. Her father Mitch, who has supported his daughter throughout her troubles, jumped on stage to join her.

Following a standing ovation, Amy, whose healthier appearance will have encouraged fans that she is on the mend after her stay in the Capio Nightingale rehab clinic, gave a short speech.

With her arm around her mother she said: “To my mum and dad. To my Blake, my Blake incarcerated.”

She also dedicated her glory to Camden – the scene of a ferocious fire at the weekend - which badly damaged her favourite hangout, The Hawley Arms.

Winehouse said: “And this is for London, this is for London, because Camden Town is burning down.”

The recognition is a sure sign the jazz singer could crack the US market, providing she can stay out of trouble and beat her demons.

Other winners on the night included Kanye West, who took home four Grammys for best rap album for Graduation, best solo rap performance for Stronger, best rap song for Good Life and best rap performance by a group for the collaboration with Common on Southside.

West paid a tribute to his mother Donda West, who died last year from complications during plastic surgery.

He said: “Mama, all I’m going to do is keep making you proud. We run this.”

The Beatles also received a tribute from Tom Hanks and Cirque du Soleil performed The Beatles Love Show.

Ringo Starr, Yoko Ono and George Harrison’s widow, Olivia Harrison, were in the audience.

Tina Turner made her first appearance on stage in seven years alongside Beyonce Knowles.

Alicia Keys opened the ceremony with Frank Sinatra’s Learnin’ the Blues, while footage of the late singer played behind her.
